item.title: Magic: The Gathering Reveals 38 Marvel Super Hero Cards Including Hulk, Doctor Doom, And Cap
item.content:encoded:
Magic: The Gathering‚Äòs Marvel Super Heroes set arrives next June, just in time for Avengers to return to theaters and Doomsday to debut at the end of the year. But the licensed Universes Beyond expansions have been at their best when they add more flavor to the trading card game rather than just lean on it for publicity. On Tuesday, Wizards of the Coast gave fans a taste of what to expect from the latest comic-book-inspired set, from Incredible Hulk card art to new Captain America card mechanics.

The company teased 38 new cards on its latest WeeklyMTG show. There‚Äôs plenty of Legendary Creatures, some neat spells, and lots of really nifty art. There‚Äôs Captain America, a 3/2 white creature with a shield counter that protects it from one instance of damage. There‚Äôs Bruce Banner, a 1/1 blue who can transform into the Hulk with an Enrage condition that gives him a +1/+1 counter when damaged and a second attack phase.

And then there‚Äôs Doctor Doom, a 3/3 black creature that enters with Doombot tokens, lets players draw a card and take damage at the end of their turn, and is indestructible while an artifact creature or Plan is on the field. Wizards also revealed a notable reprint of Heroic Intervention, with the effect of ‚ÄúPermanents you control gain hexproof and indestructible until end of turn.‚Äù The set has a Horn of Greed, too, with the perfect Doctor Doom ‚Äútoot‚Äù art.

While the reprints each have callbacks to some classic Marvel comic book art, my favorite-looking cards so far are the full-art variants of Widow-Making Infiltrator, Dig Through Time, and Elektra, Deadly Assassin. And for all your Saga nerds out there, we have World War Hulk, which ends with doubling a creature‚Äôs power and toughness and giving it trample, and The Coming of Galactus, which culminates in a 16/16 black Elder Alien with flying, trample, and ‚ÄúWhenever Galactus attacks, destroy target land.‚Äù

I wasn‚Äôt too impressed with the Marvel set when it was initially revealed earlier this year. Coming right after Spider-Man and in the midst of a glut of other Universes Beyond crossovers, it seemed likely to be another property stretched thin and rushed out to keep the release calendar rolling. These initial card reveals look promising, though. I‚Äôm intrigued. Maybe I wasn‚Äôt as burnt out on Marvel as I thought. I might just have to chase Galactus after all.

item.title: AirPods Pro 3 Return to Black Friday Record Low on Amazon, Apple Store Still Charges Full Price
item.content:encoded:
Apple never puts its newest products on sale, especially not something as new as the AirPods Pro 3 which came out just a few months ago. But Amazon has taken matters into its own hands and cut prices on almost all of Apple‚Äôs products right before Christmas. For instance, you can get these third-generation AirPods Pro for $219 instead of the usual $249 which is the same price as the lowest price we saw on Black Friday. You might be tempted to buy the older AirPods Pro 2 because they are cheaper, but this newer model has so many more features powered by Apple Intelligence that if you don‚Äôt upgrade, you‚Äôll miss out on features that change the way you use wireless earbuds.

See at Amazon

Efficient Noise Cancellation

Apple says that the AirPods Pro 3 block out twice as much unwanted noise as the already-great Pro 2 model ‚Äì and it means that subway rumble, airplane engine drone, and coffee shop chatter almost completely disappear. The active noise cancellation changes in real time based on the shape of your ear canal and the fit of the ear tips and keeps changing to keep out as much outside noise as possible. The box now comes with five different ear tip sizes instead of the three it used to have to make sure you can find a snug fit that makes the best seal for the best noise cancellation and bass response.

The audio architecture was completely changed to focus on what Apple calls ‚Äúthree-dimensional sound,‚Äù which makes music feel like it‚Äôs happening around you instead of inside your head. Bass hits with more depth and power without drowning out the midrange, and high frequencies give you clear detail that lets you hear each instrument in a complicated arrangement. The vocals are very clear and present, putting the singers right in front of you in the soundstage. When you turn your head, spatial audio with dynamic head tracking keeps sound sources anchored to your iPhone or iPad which makes for an immersive experience that is especially fun when watching movies or playing games.

One of the most useful new features of the AirPods Pro 3 is heart rate sensing: It turns your earbuds into workout partners that can track your heart rate and calorie burn for 50 different types of exercise. This information syncs with the Activity app on your iPhone, adding to your Move ring and step count. It also gives you useful information through the new Workout Buddy feature powered by Apple Intelligence.

Live Translation uses Apple Intelligence to process speech and give instant translations that sound natural: This breaks down language barriers in real-time conversations. Think about going to another country and being able to talk to people there without having to pull out your phone or look for a translation app: The feature works with many languages and gets better as Apple Intelligence learns from more interactions. Active Hearing Protection keeps an eye on the noise levels in your environment all the time and it lowers the volume when you‚Äôre around sounds that could hurt your ears, like construction work, concerts, or loud traffic.

The Hearing Aid feature uses the great fit and noise processing to work as a clinical-grade hearing aid, complete with automatic Conversation Boost to boost speech frequencies. You can even use your iPhone and AirPods Pro 3 to take a hearing test at home which will give you personalized audio profiles that make listening to music, calls, and media more enjoyable. With active noise cancellation turned on, the battery lasts for eight hours and with Transparency mode and hearing aid functionality turned on, the battery lasts for up to ten hours.

It might not sound like much, but Apple products don‚Äôt usually go on sale this soon after they come out, so this price is very good by Apple‚Äôs standards. You can get flagship earbuds at a lower price before the holiday shopping season ends because Amazon matched the Black Friday record low in mid-December. You‚Äôre buying earbuds that work as fitness trackers, hearing aids, translation devices, and high-end audio equipment all in one package which makes the price worth it even before the discount is taken into account.

item.title: New Brandon Sanderson Sci-Fi Book Is 30% Off On Launch Day
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Fantasy and science fiction readers can add another Brandon Sanderson book to the to-be-read pile. Tailored Realities, a lengthy collection of novellas and short stories, is available now, and Amazon is offering a 30% discount on launch day (December 9). The hardcover edition of Tailored Realities is on sale for only $21 (was $30).. Walmart had the same deal, but the retailer is currently sold out of copies.

If you're interested in buying the book as a gift for a Sanderson fan, you should order a copy soon. Amazon currently estimates a December 19-21 delivery window for Prime members. Tailored Realities is also available in ebook and audiobook formats. The collection made Amazon's list of the best science fiction and fantasy books of December 2025.

Brandon Sanderson - Tailored Realities (Hardcover)

$21 (was $30)

Tailored Realities is a 448-page collection featuring 10 novellas and short stories. Though Sanderson is largely known as a fantasy author, Tailored Realities skews more toward science fiction. The biggest story is Moment Zero, a brand-new novel of roughly 200 pages. This apocalyptic sci-fi story follows two police officers who, while investigating a disappearance, find themselves in an alternate dimension filled with zombies and vampires.

Moment Zero is one of two alternate-reality sci-fi novellas included in Tailored Realities. The collection also features Snapshot, a 2017 sci-fi thriller starring two detectives who investigate a murder from within a dangerous virtual reconstruction of the past. Snapshot's original hardcover edition was 128 pages.

The third novella in Tailored Realities is Perfect State. Originally published in 2015, Perfect State follows a god-like ruler's first date with a goddess-like ruler of a different world. The highly rated novella is roughly 90 pages.

None of the stories take place in Sanderson's Cosmere--the shared universe of The Stormlight Archive and Mistborn--but two shorter novellas are connected to his popular YA franchises. Defending Elysium is a prequel to Sanderson's science fiction series Skyward. Mitosis is a side story that takes place between the first and second books in the superhero-action series The Reckoners.

The novellas are joined by five short stories, including "Firstborn" and "Dreamer," which follows deceased gamers who take control of living humans to play high stakes games.

Tailored Realities Stories:

  • Moment Zero: A Novella
  • Snapshot: A Novella
  • Perfect State: A Novella
  • Defending Elysium: A Novella (Skyward)
  • Mitosis: A Novella (Reckoners)
  • Firstborn
  • Brain Dump
  • Probability Approaching Zero
  • Dreamer
  • I Hate Dragons

Brandon Sanderson: Skyward and Reckoners Box Set Deals

If you haven't read Reckoners or Skyward, Amazon has deals on box sets for both series. A slipcased box set collecting all four Skyward novels released last month and is on sale for $41.31 (was $60). If you prefer hardcover books, you'll want to check out Skyward's 3-Book Box Set for $39 and pick up a copy of the final novel, Defiant, for $12 (was $21).

  • Skyward 3-Book Hardcover Box Set -- $39 ($64)
  • Skyward 3-Book Paperback Box Set -- $31.48 ($45)

As mentioned, the Skyward novella in Tailored Realities is a prequel, so you don't need to read the main series first. With the novella from the Reckoners series, however, you should probably wait to read it until you at least read Steelheart, the first novel in the series. The Reckoners Series Box Set is available in paperback and hardcover for $33 and $45, respectively.

If you're interested in checking out Sanderson's epic fantasy novels set in the fictional universe known as the Cosmere, one of Amazon's Black Friday book box set deals is still available as of December 9. The Mistborn Trilogy Paperback Box Set is on sale for only $15.32 (was $35). Amazon previously had The Stormlight Archive 3-Book Paperback Box Set for only $17, but the price has since risen to $25 (was $39). The Stormlight Archive 4-Book Hardcover Box Set is actually slightly cheaper than its Black Friday price. The $160 slipcased set is available for only $72.68. The total page count for this weighty box set is 4,576. The fifth and latest novel in the series, Wind and Truth, is on sale for $16.30 (was $40) in hardcover. Wind and Truth is the longest entry in the series at 1,344 pages.

item.title: Pokemon Legends: Z-A Is Giving Away A Very Big Charizard
item.content:encoded:

The Pokemon Company is giving away another free gift for Pokemon Legends: Z-A players. Ahead of the game's Mega Dimension DLC, you can snag a mighty alpha Charizard for a limited time.

On top of being much larger than a typical Charizard, this particular Pokemon is level 36 and knows Solar Beam--a move Charizard normally can only learn via TM. This should make it a helpful partner to have on your team when facing off against the overleveled Pokemon that reside in Hyperspace Lumiose.

To claim the free alpha Charizard, fire up your copy of Pokemon Legends: Z-A and do the following:

  1. Press X to open the menu
  2. Select Link Play
  3. Select Mystery Gift
  4. Choose Get with Code/Password
  5. Input the code B1G006 and download the gift
  6. Save your game

This code will only be valid until January 19, 2026, so you have until then to claim the free Pokemon.

This isn't the only free gift you can get right now in Pokemon Legends: Z-A. The Pokemon Company is also giving away Mega Stones for Diancie and Mewtwo. Once you've claimed the stones and cleared the main story, you can undertake special side quests to catch the two legendary Pokemon.

Pokemon Legends: Z-A's Mega Dimension DLC launches on December 10. This expansion adds new story content that takes Team MZ into Hyperspace Lumiose, an alternate dimension where players will encounter wild Pokemon over level 100. The DLC also introduces a handful of new Mega Evolutions like Mega Zeraora and Mega Lucario Z.

item.title: We Think We Know What Geoff Keighley's Weird Desert Statue Is Teasing
item.content:encoded:
And yeah, it's pretty cool.

Earlier this month, a large, demonic-looking monolith appeared in the Mojave Desert, and Geoff Keighley tweeted a photo of it. The monolith featured figures of all sorts of strange creators: skeletons, alligators, soldiers, a wolf, and more. In the time since, online gaming enthusiasts have been eagerly speculating as to what the monolith and Keighley were teasing ahead of The Game Awards. Diablo 4? The Elder Scrolls 6? God of War? Bloodborne 2? Altered Beast?

Well, the mystery may have been solved in advance of The Game Awards on Thursday. As spotted by MP1st, some newly registered trademarks reveal a game and a logo that looks essentially identical to a symbol on the monolith. And those trademarks appear to be for a new Divinity game, from Larian Studios.

How do we know? Well, let's take a look at one of the trademarks. It's for an image, and it looks like this:

Now compare that to the big symbol at the center of the statue:

So yeah, that's definitely the same symbol, so we're in the right place. Now, how do we know it's Divinity? Let's look at the next trademark registered at the same time by the same company, simply for "Divinity", with a logo attached.

Now we're getting somewhere! It's not exact, but it's quite comparable to past Divinity: Original Sin logos:

And even closer to the older Divinity games, slashed through "i" and all.

Okay, maybe it's all just a big coincidence? Sure, I guess. But there's one more clue. All three trademarks were filed by Ihde & Partner Rechtsanw√§lte, a legal firm that, among other things, has previously filed trademarks for Larian Studios, including past Divinity: Original Sin trademarks.

So that's pretty cut and dry. But what about that third trademark? This is where things get a bit more mysterious. This trademark is also just for an image, this one here:

What's that? I have no idea. But it's probably related, given it was filed on the same day by the same firm and is in a similar style to the other trademarks. Maybe we'll find out on Thursday.

Critically, this seems to be for a new Divinity...NOT a Divinity: Original Sin game. Director of publishing at Larian Studios Michael Douse was on Twitter/X today shutting down any rumors of a Divinity: Original Sin 3, but his language was very specific:

There aren't currently any plans for a new Divinity Original Sin 3 game but once we are ready to show what we've been working on we will üôè

‚Äî Very AFK (@Cromwelp) December 9, 2025

If this is indeed Divinity, that's good news for Larian fans, as Divinity: Original Sin 2 was fantastic. We gave it a 9.6/10, saying, "Divinity: Original Sin 2 may have been designed in the spirit of decades-old RPGs like Baldur‚Äôs Gate 2, but that legacy serves only as a foundation for the expansive game Larian has built on top of it."

Speaking of Baldur's Gate, Baldur's Gate 3 is Larian's most recent work, and that got an impressive 10/10 from us. We said, "I don't want to say every CRPG going forward should aspire to be like Baldur's Gate 3. Not everything needs to be nearly this big and ambitious, or even this dense. But it is a landmark moment in the genre, and if I had to point to one paragon that I would like everyone else making these to take inspiration from, this is absolutely it."

While some may have clamored for Larian to immediately get to work on DLC or Baldur's Gate 4, Larian explicitly said over a year ago that it wouldn't be continuing with another D&D game. However, Larian CEO Swen Vincke has been teasing a new project for a while now, and based on past timelines, this year's Game Awards would be a perfect time for an unveiling.

Rebekah Valentine is a senior reporter for IGN. Got a story tip? Send it to rvalentine@ign.com.

item.title: McDonalds Got Bullied So Badly It Deleted Its AI Christmas Ad
item.content:encoded:
Earlier this month, McDonald‚Äôs Netherlands put out an ugly and lifeless Christmas commercial that was created using AI generation tools. Over the weekend, after the ad spot went viral online for all the wrong reasons, the fast-food chain deleted it.

Recently, McDonald‚Äôs followed in the footsteps of Coca-Cola and released a new AI-generated advertisement just in time for the holiday season. The ad features numerous AI-generated scenes of people dealing with all the horrible, annoying, and not-so-great moments that can happen during this time of year. It‚Äôs genuinely a funny little idea for an ad, but it‚Äôs hard to watch and enjoy when it‚Äôs so clearly AI-generated.

This is normally the part where I‚Äôd embed the ad via an official source, like the McDonald‚Äôs YouTube account. But, as spotted by Futurism, I can‚Äôt do that because the fast food company has seemingly removed it entirely from the internet, a step it took after previously shutting down comments on the ad. So here‚Äôs a reupload of it via the YouTube channel CongenAI:

Perhaps the wildest part of all of this is that the studio behind the awful-looking AI ad claimed that it crunched for weeks to produce this slop. Seriously. Here‚Äôs the full statement from the studio, Sweetshop, which has also since been deleted:

‚ÄúFor seven weeks, we hardly slept, with up to 10 of our in-house AI and post specialists at The Gardening Club working in lockstep with the directors. Every shot travelled through a rigorously engineered toolchain: real Google Earth plates, advanced style-transfer, pixel-level photo repair, custom LoRAs, control nets, bespoke ComfyUI graphs, and thousands upon thousands of tightly steered iterations.

Then came compositing, lighting balance, physics corrections, artefact removal, and final finishing in Flame. We generated what felt like dailies ‚Äì thousands of takes ‚Äì then shaped them in the edit just as we would on any high-craft production. This wasn‚Äôt an AI trick. It was a film. And here‚Äôs the thing I wish more people understood: magic isn‚Äôt the technology. The magic is the team behind it, people who pushed, questioned, experimented, swore at broken models, solved impossible problems, and refused to stop until every frame felt cinematic.

I don‚Äôt see this spot as a novelty or a cute seasonal experiment. To me, it‚Äôs evidence of something much bigger: that when craft and technology meet with intention, they can create work that feels genuinely cinematic. So no ‚Äì AI didn‚Äôt make this film. We did.‚Äù

Personally, I think it would be easier and better to just have a camera crew and a director film some actors, maybe add some stock footage in, and not make something horrible in a way that sounds both tedious and terrible. But I‚Äôm just old-fashioned like that, I guess.

item.title: No Current Plans for Divinity: Original Sin 3, Larian Says
item.content:encoded:
The Divinity series has been the talk of the town lately after it was uncovered that the mysterious statue for The Game Awards could be related to the 23-year-old franchise. One such hope from fans is that the announcement, should it be true, is that Divinity: Original Sin 3 is on the way.

If you‚Äôre one of those fans hoping for that, you may want to sit down.

While answering fan questions on social media, Laraian Studio‚Äôs head of publishing Michael Douse poured some sand on that fire‚Äîyes, sand is good to put out small fires.

In a response to one fan asking, ‚ÄúDivinity Original Sin 3 when???‚Äù, Douse said there are no current plans for the game. However, he didn‚Äôt say there weren‚Äôt any plans for Divinity as a whole.

‚ÄúThere aren‚Äôt currently any plans for a new Divinity Original Sin 3 game, but once we are ready to show what we‚Äôve been working on we will,‚Äù he said.

While the new announcement may not be for Divinity: Original Sin 3, there remains plenty of smoke that Divinity will have a major presence at Thursday‚Äôs The Game Awards. Maybe even a new game titled something completely different, but in the series.

One rumor also making the rounds is that Larian is set to announce Divinity: Original Sin 2 ‚Äì Definitive Edition for PlayStation 5 and, possibly, Xbox Series X|S.

Whether that‚Äôs the only announcement or something even bigger is planned, it feels like fans of Larian Studios will have something to talk about soon enough.

item.title: Alien Star In Talks to Star in Prime Video‚Äôs Tomb Raider
item.content:encoded:
According to a new report, Sigourney Weaver may be in talks to star in Prime Video‚Äôs Tomb Raider series. The Oscar-nominated actress, if confirmed, would join Game of Thrones‚Äô Sophie Turner, who‚Äôs set to play protagonist Lara Croft.

Starting in 1996, the Tomb Raider series has become a gaming icon, spawning multiple games, a reboot, and much more. It‚Äôs had three live-action films starring Angelina Jolie and Alicia Vikander. While a sequel to the 2018 film was cancelled, a new live-action adaptation of the iconic Tomb Raider series was announced by Prime Video last year. With Fleabag‚Äôs Phoebe Waller-Bridge as creator, writer, and executive producer, the show has set its sights on finally bringing the series to Hollywood successfully. Fortunately, if the latest casting is any indication, it could reach those lofty heights.

Sigourney Weaver In Talks for Prime Video‚Äôs Tomb Raider Series Starring Sophie Turner

According to a report from Deadline, actress Sigourney Weaver, known for her work in Alien and Avatar, is in talks to star in Prime Video‚Äôs Tomb Raider. It‚Äôs not known if the Oscar-nominated actress will take the undisclosed role, so take it with a grain of salt. If true, she would join Sophie Turner and All-American: Homecoming‚Äôs Martin Bobb-Semple, who was added last week.

If confirmed, Sigourney Weaver would be a major steal for the series. The actress has starred in multiple blockbusters like Aliens, Ghostbusters, Galaxy Quest, and Avatar. She has been nominated for three Academy Awards, two for Best Actress (Aliens and Gorillas in the Mist) and one for Best Supporting Actress (Working Girl). Furthermore, she is appearing in Avatar: Fire and Ash and The Mandalorian & Grogu in major roles.

Given how popular the Tomb Raider franchise is (and the already stacked cast and crew), it‚Äôs not a surprise to see Sigourney come on board. The future of the series is an exciting one, as fans will find out more on December 11th at The Game Awards. Filming for the show is starting in February 2026, so more information may be revealed prior to starting. Until then, it‚Äôs certainly a good time to be a Tomb Raider fan.

item.title: The Game Awards Creator Hears Your Feedback --"Do We Always Get It Right? No"
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The Game Awards host and organizer Geoff Keighley has opened up on the challenges of running a show that aims to celebrate games and the people who make them while also acknowledging the challenging times people in the industry today are facing. So far in 2025, numerous developers lost their jobs, Microsoft canceled games, and the industry further consolidated with EA announcing plans to sell itself to Saudi Arabia.

Speaking to The Game Business, Keighley said the introduction of the Game Changer award in 2024 was an initial attempt to address this. Amir Satvat was given the prize for his work to support people who were laid off in the gaming industry.

Keighley hasn't said if this award is coming back in 2025, but it would be a glaring omission if it did not. In any event, Keighley said walking the line between celebrating games and acknowledging current circumstances is no easy task.

"It's a very difficult needle to thread, because on one level, it is a celebration of the industry. But the games are made by incredible developers, and it‚Äôs been a challenging period overall. I don't have all the answers about the right way to [address it]."

Keighley went on to say he feels a "weight" on his shoulders to do more because The Game Awards has such a large platform. But at the same time, Keighley said he understands that people watch the show to see their favorite games get celebrated and get hyped for the news and reveals.

"How we square that is something that we think a lot about. Some people online think that we're oblivious to it. We're definitely thinking about the right way to represent the industry to the wider world. Do we always get it right? No. It's a very complex situation to figure out exactly what to do," he said.

People have also criticized The Game Awards (and numerous other entertainment awards shows, for that matter) for not being more heavily focused on the awards themselves, and instead also serving as a marketing events for games. Each year, people regularly criticize the event for zipping through the awards themselves and giving developers a limited time to speak while time and attention is paid to trailers and advertisements from sponsors.

"There are many different constituents that tune in," he said. "And it is a balancing act. "There's the awards aspect of the show, there's the announcement aspect, and yes, there are some people that would like to see the show be all awards. Some would like to see all announcements."

Keighley said his take is that the promise of exciting announcements help create a "very wide audience" for who might want to watch the show. More people watching to see the brand-new reveals--including whatever the heck that scary monolith is--will in turn create increased viewership for when the awards are handed out. Or at least that's how Keighley sees it and explains it, and he shared some anecdotes that back up his claims, to an extent.

"My view always is that the announcements create a very wide audience that tunes into the show. And because of that, when we do give out these awards, they're seen by a lot of people," he said. "Lots of games get sold out of The Game Awards. Balatro had a huge boost. So hopefully it's a good thing for developers. But that careful balance is a hard thing to strike and we don't always get it right."

The Game Awards takes place on Thursday, December 11, beginning at 5 PM PT / 8 PM ET, with a pre-show set to begin 30 minutes prior. Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 picked up 12 nominations overall, including a nod for Game of the Year, and is the most-nominated game in the history of the show.

After 25 years of being exclusive on console to Xbox, Microsoft's Halo series is headed to PlayStation in 2026 with Halo: Campaign Evolved. With the year coming to a close, Sony has published a video highlighting some of the "must-play" titles coming to PS5 in 2026, and Halo got a special shoutout in the video, while GTA 6 was not mentioned.

Seeing Halo promoted so heavily by Sony would have been unthinkable not long ago, and the comments on the video reflect this. The top comment on the video states, "Seeing Halo here is still surreal." Someone else said, "It feels so weird seeing Halo being advertised by PlayStation."

item.title: What Have We Done To Deserve Such Wonderful Sons?
item.content:encoded:
What does it take to raise three gargantuan, perfect boys? And what kind of crazy mix-ups would those beautiful, gentle giants get into? This is the central theme of Joe Cappa‚Äôs Haha, You Clowns, possibly the strangest show in the last year and one of the strongest animated works that Adult Swim has produced since Smiling Friends. Isaiah Colbert and Chris Person sat down and talked about what it takes to raise such wonderful sons.

Chris: I think I became aware of this because Bakoon kept posting out of context clips of it. How did you end up finding out about this?

Isaiah: My first brush with it was a bit less happenstance. What with me being a cat in both worlds of gaming and animation, I wound up getting sent screeners of the show prior to its release in my emails.  An occurrence that's usually random AF and results in me getting spammed with Prime Video shows no one's ever heard of and I will never watch, but I was taken aback by how its character designs all looked like palatable Wojack memes. But, turns out, it‚Äôs quite the opposite of that. It's pretty damn pleasant. Downright wholesome.

Chris: I love these boys so much.

Isaiah: The elevator pitch for it is pretty much what you said, so it‚Äôs almost hard to describe the show beyond that. But if I were to attempt to do so, I'd say the show is about a family who lifts strangers up as often as they do each other as they learn to live together following the loss of their mom. Granted, it's a surreal-looking show to experience watching, with its characters looking like they wandered out of an MS Paint draft, but its humor is starkly anti-cynical. I think that's the magic of the whole thing.

Chris: Yeah, it's a hard show to explain the premise of without just watching it. I tried showing my dad this show over Thanksgiving. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about three giant boys and their father and looks really troubling. You keep expecting something very bad to happen but if it does it's immediately resolved. By the end of every episode, they all learn a lesson and grow closer.‚Äù We watched exactly one episode, my dad laughed, and he said ‚ÄúOK, enough of that.‚Äù In retrospect, I was just describing a sitcom. 

Isaiah: Basically, yet I think its look being so off-putting is what's kept it from really being an easy on-ramp show to get folks to watch. When I broach watching it with my friends after twisting their arm to rewatch specific Smiling Friends episodes at my request, they get turned off by the look of it. But after showing my partner the three episodes stretch from episodes 3-5, I think that's when its formula broke my partner down into liking it. In a weird way, the show having swole dudes who look like the friends of a friend you don't want to hang out with at a party acts as a way to deconstruct implicit biases. That even meatheads can be sweet boys. And seeing them make a mountain out of the smallest thing‚Äìsearching for a lost jacket in a restaurant, comforting their dad on a rocky flight, teaching their younger brother to not be afraid of holding a baby‚Äìis almost an act of anti-comedy that comes back around as comedy when put against how intentionally weird looking the show is. It grows on you.

Boo to all those people on Twitter that shat on the show for airing after Smiling Friends as if it were some Walmart double feature movie package deal that nobody wanted. I think they complement each other well, what with one being meaner despite its name and the other being wholesome despite how bowling shoe ugly its designs are.

Chris: Right, and the execution is the point. If you have to pinpoint what is "funny" about the show, it's often just how specific actions are animated or just tiny, uncomfortable turns of phrases. Tristan, Preston and Duncan are all voiced by Joe Cappa and have a diction somewhere between Schwarzenegger and Homestar Runner. I actually think it bizarrely shares a lot in common with the latter, as well as Brad Neely's work or maybe Achewood a little. There's an entire episode about Duncan being afraid of holding a baby that destroyed me just based on single, tiny shots of how strange babies look. Or even just the fact that their neighbor is professional pool player Jeanette "Black Widow" Lee, who is dating Sean Astin. It's just these specific beats in an otherwise wholesome show.

Isaiah: Biblically accurate Sean Astin had me rolling. They got his eye tilt so dead-on from all angles. 

Chris: It's cool that both Lee and Astin signed on for this knowing what it looks like.

Isaiah: I think another thing that probably Adult Swim should get more credit for is that many of its newer animated shows are from folks who just did animation on Newgrounds and YouTube for years as folks to take a chance on to give them these series. Cappa and Smiling Friends creators Michael Cusack and Zach Hadel are so terminally online have done this as a passion for so long that it really shows in their series. That uncanny ability to spotlight how drawing something like giving your dad a massage or naturalistic, rambling dialogue about something so innocuous and random like male-pattern balding and finding humor in how relatable that kind of banter is.

A secret thing I've been doing in the lag time of new episodes is going back to the creators' old stuff and discovering the genesis for what would be their first drafts of these jokes. For Hadel, a lot of it is random appearances on Oneyplays where his hypothetical inferences, vocal stims, and impersonations find new life in the show. The same can be said for Cappa, because the first drafts of Haha, You Clowns exist on his YouTube account. And honestly, the first one I saw I didn't like as much because it was a bit crass and mean spirited from the good boys I know and love. So witnessing that evolve into the wholesome show it is now has been a great thing to retroactively experience. It's kind of like how a mangaka will have the core premise of their landmark series in a one shot and seeing how relationships and designs carry over and are remixed for the better. Though, I did get a kick out of the YouTube series' running gag being that the mom was, in fact, a ghostly presence instead of being a knockoff Alexa. 

Though I'll take their eyes turning red whenever they inevitably start crying and the after school-ass Yakuza substory piano music that starts playing over it any day of the week. 

Chris: Yeah I think the final show works better because it firmly loves the boys. I remember someone a while back saying the difference between Family Guy and American Dad is that the family in American Dad seems to really like each other and that's why it's a better show. Like it really does grow on you. Cappa's entire account is wild though, his stuff involving really weird practical effects like ‚ÄúMeet The Boys‚Äù is great. It all has a menacing Aphex Twin ‚ÄúWindowlicker‚Äù tension that is never resolved.

Isaiah: When I read up on him before our chat, I came across his animated short ‚ÄúGhost Dogs,‚Äù which has motion as a Sundance Festival Official Selection and the Satoshi Kon Award winner at Fantasia. Watching it was creepy as hell. But dude's definitely got artistic range. I tend to trust folks who can seamlessly weave their way from comedy to horror, and ‚ÄúGhost Dogs‚Äù is definitely horror. 

Chris: Yeah, like Smiling Friends does a lot with not being locked into a single medium and working with multiple (CG, claymation). I don't think I'd want that for this show, but it helps as an artist and animator to have the range.

Isaiah: I feel forever changed having learned that the animators for Haha, You Clowns draw the first initials of the boys to tell them apart because, despite not being triplets, they have the same fucking face. 

With Haha, You Clowns being the first Adult Swim short to be picked up as a series, I hope it leads more shows of its ilk to get a rocket strapped to its pack and propelled into the mainstream. My kingdom for a full series-funded pick up for YouTube animated shows like Speedoru's Punch Punch Forever or MeatCanyon getting some sort of show. 

Chris: I would very much love it if Adult Swim had free rein to do that. It exists as this strange unicorn when so much of animation is decimated, and it's worrying particularly since Williams Street is a subsidiary of Warner Brothers.

Isaiah: Lord knows, Warner Bros. under Netflix would all but assure nothing is getting past a second season. Good news for that ‚Äúwhy bother?‚Äù Hogwarts show. Bad news for animation worth a damn.

Chris: I can't imagine that. I want these large lads to have a healthy life. I want to see their adventures for years. I wanna grow old with these beautiful boys.

Isaiah: Haha, You Clowns forever. A hundred years, Haha, You Clowns things, and stuff of that nature.

item.title: Dirt bike through the nature-encrusted ruins of post-apocalyptic 80s Germany in youthful adventure Verdant
item.content:encoded:
A "bittersweet journey of discovery" as to how everything ended some flowery and skeletony awaits

The world's ended, but doesn't it look pretty? That seems to be the central premise of Verdant, a game in which a young bloke dirt bikes around the plant-filled remains of post-apocalyptic 1980s Germany, figuring out the conundrums all young dirt bikers face.

As someone who loves a good game about lone youngsters with big backpacks venturing into the unknown, the blend of soothing, flowery nature and darker undertones - as skeletons sit in abandoned cars - that Verdant offers really intrigues me. It seems there'll be as much chill camping amid runs as there is poking the barrel of your gun into hidden nooks, trying to work out what the heck turned the place into one big garden centre. The soundtrack's a charming blend of tinkly piano interspersed with bursts of synth, a contrast I also dig.

German devs Tiny Roar also emphasise, in their synopsis, that Verdant is as much about its dirt biker finding where they fit in the world's future as it is about dredging through the past. And touching deer, so they get even more plant-encusted. Hopefully there'll be plenty of depth to all these elements, rather than just surface-level emoting.

The biggest question I'm left with, following the reveal during today's Wholesome Snack showcase, is just how big Verdant's environment will feel as you're roaming around it. While actually having massive scale isn't necessary, maintaining the illusion that you're just a small speck amid a giant ocean of unknown possibility or threat is what makes the likes of similar backpackish youngster adventure Keep Driving tick.

You're just a little dude, sitting in a car or at a campsite, surrounded by the whole. It's your puzzle, or your cage, or your playhouse. Usually all three at various times.

As of right now, Verdant is without a release date, but you can wishlist it on Steam if you're so inclined.

item.title: You owe the giant horned cat money in Mandrake, the Sunless Sea devs' British folklore-steeped gardening sim
item.content:encoded:
The Yolf is on the verge of sending some lads around to break your legs

Pay up then. Sorry, I've been sent on behalf of The Yolf, a giant horned cat creature who sits on a branch demanding payment in Mandrake. This folklore-infused gardening sim from Sunless Sea and Fallen London devs Failbetter games has just had a fresh outing at today's Wholesome Snack showcase, putting centre-stage the The Yolf's need for you to get your affairs in order.

You play a farmer keen to do some gardening, despite curses and weird folkloric beings making that a bit harder. The Yolf, Failbetter say, lives next door. He's a "furry, friendly neighbour who nonetheless demands payment for debts owed to him by your ancestors". He'll only take cash for this sum of 962 gold crowns, as well.

To make that up, you'll have to get your sorcerer bottom in gear and plant some stuff. The game has goose trees, they sound like a good bet, especially if they turn out to be golden. You can also go foraging, fishing, and mining in "a world of old, wild powers, of uncanny spirits that reside in those places mortals dare not go; of deep histories, and deeper mysteries". It seems the more dangerous uncanny beings only come out at night, with the game warning you about going out once the sun sets.

The thing that's most intrigued me, aside from the gorgeously vibrant art style, is the chance to run around the sleepy rural hollow of Chandley having chats with people, spirits, gods, and bogles via dialogue boxes that remind me of a laid-back version of Disco Elysium's portrait-side word scrawls. Then again, Failbetter also say you can do the following, all of which sounds rad: "Befriend a river. Eavesdrop on the dead. Spend a haunted night at the Butcher's Oak. Drink tea with the god who lives in your chimney."

Anyway, your job is to grow produce and redecorate the old mandrake lodge you'll be calling home. There's no cannibalism involved, or so the devs say.

Mandrake's still release-dateless as of right now, but you can wishlist it on Steam. If you're keen for a long read outlining how it came to be and the path it's been on to this point, I'll point you to this piece former RPSer Alice B penned for Perfectly Cylindical Gamer upon its reveal this summer.

Publisher tinyBuild and I Am Future developer Mandragora have announced ReStory, a simulation game that lets you run your own electronics repair shop in Y2K-era Japan. It will launch for PC via Steam in 2026.

‚ÄúReStory is my nostalgia for a time when we shared polyphonic ringtones via infrared ports and rewound cassette tapes with a pencil,‚Äù said Mandragora studio director Evgeny Kisterev in a press release. ‚ÄúWhen every device felt unique. Now we just hold these screens in our hands, and they all look the same. Japanese companies always amazed me with their influence on global technology, which made 2000s Tokyo the perfect setting. I can‚Äôt wait to share this nostalgic feeling with players and discover how many other grown-up kids remember that era fondly!‚Äù

  • ‚ùÆ
  • ‚ùØ

Here is an overview of the game, via tinyBuild:

About

ReStory lets you run your own electronics repair shop in Y2K-era Japan. Fix iconic pieces of 2000s tech, like cell phones, video game consoles (including officially licensed Atari systems), handhelds, digital pets, home appliances, music players, cameras, and more‚Äîall while hearing the unique stories of your customers and making meaningful decisions that influence a branching storyline.

ReStory combines tactile repair gameplay with the relaxing atmosphere, shop management mechanics, and a cast of memorable characters. Grow your business by carefully unscrewing, cleaning, soldering, repainting, and assembling devices to bring them back to life‚Äîand if you need spare parts, you can always buy them online via an old-school in-game web browser. Talk to customers, hear their stories, and see how your decisions impact both their lives and your shop through a non-linear narrative.

Key Features

  • Satisfying Gadget Repairs ‚Äì Chill out and vibe with engaging device restoration mechanics through every step of the tech-repair process.
  • Shop Management ‚Äì Take orders, manage your finances, browse the web and hunt for spare parts.
  • Impactful Narrative ‚Äì Meet a memorable cast of characters with unpredictable and intertwining stories. Your decisions will impact both their lives and your shop.
  • Y2K Nostalgia ‚Äì Fix devices inspired by iconic gaming consoles & handhelds, portable music players, cameras, home appliances and cell phones of the 2000s.
  • Wait, Is That an Atari?! ‚Äì Yes! Partnering with Atari, ReStory will feature licensed consoles to repair including the Atari 2600, Jaguar and more!
  • Chill Atmosphere ‚Äì ReStory creates a relaxing atmosphere that lets you unwind and tinker with gadgets against a beautiful backdrop of the Japanese urban setting.

Cozy Caravan lets you embark on an expedition where the arts of crafting, trading, and exploration come together in an enchanting, adorable world. Create your own cuddly alter-ego and explore open roads with your trusty caravan alongside your best buddy Bubba, setting up mobile markets as you sojourn from town to town. Craft a variety of items through delightful mini-games, then set up your market and trade with the locals.

Experience the warmth of small-town charm with every friendly gesture along the way. Encounter a rich tapestry of characters with their own stories and quests, deepening the sense of connection and community on your travels. Stop and say hello to the local townsfolk and join in on fun activities. And keep an eye out, you never know where you might find someone who could use a lift!

item.title: Lush post-apocalyptic adventure game Verdant announced for PC
item.content:encoded:
• PC

Survive a beautiful yet harsh world.

Publisher Megabit and developer Tiny Roar have announced Verdant, an adventure game set in a lush post-apocalyptic world. It will be available for PC via Steam. A release date was not announced.

‚ÄúVerdant is a hopeful coming-of-age story,‚Äù said Tiny Roar co-founder and Verdant director Maurice Hagelstein in a press release. ‚ÄúThroughout Sprout‚Äôs journey players will encounter difficult moral choices and moments of poignant nostalgia as they balance their own survival against the needs of the natural world. We‚Äôre excited to show players more of Verdant in the future.‚Äù

Here is an overview of the game, via its Steam page:

About

Accompany Sprout on his journey through the green post-apocalyptic world of Verdant. Survive the beautiful yet harsh environment by building camps and upgrading your gear. Balance life and death literally in your hand with your powers and uncover their connection to the downfall of humanity.

Key Features

  • Explore a Changed World ‚Äì After a devastating war, the world has fundamentally changed. Flora and fauna have mutated and reclaimed cities while human technology and culture have not moved on from the 1980s. Piece together the story of how the world changed and determine your role in building its future.
  • Be the Catalyst ‚Äì Use Sprout‚Äôs unique powers to take and bestow life essence from nature to shape the world around you. Will you decide to absorb an innocent deer to heal yourself, or use its essence to cleanse the small stream ahead? The choice may be difficult, but it is yours to make.
  • Prepare for Every Possibility ‚Äì The world of Verdant may look beautiful, but many dangers lurk within its lush greenery. As you journey through the lands, you‚Äôll need to gather resources, craft and upgrade your gear and think fast if you want to survive.
  • Ensure your Survival ‚Äì As an inexperienced fighter with limited firepower, you‚Äôll need to rely on your wits to avoid and outsmart enemies. Staying hydrated, well-fed and rested is just as important to your survival; the rumbling of a hungry stomach can alert nearby animals and lack of sleep can lead your mind to play tricks on you.
